Constructor & Destructor Documentation

WindowEffect (  long  time,
Window *  window
) 
 

Creates a new window effect.

After creation, add the effect to the Desktop.

Parameters:
time The total time of the effect in milli seconds. If the effect is repetitive, this is the time of one loop.
window The window the effect is defined for.
See also:
Desktop::addEffect()

Member Function Documentation

void addReference (   )  [inherited]
 

Increases a reference count by one.

void cancel (   )  [inherited]
 

Cancels the effect.

Canceled effects are not executed anymore. The desktop calls cancel(DrawingContext) next time it processes events and then destroys it automatically.

virtual void draw (  DrawingContext &  context  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Draws the effect, if this effect causes a visualization.

Usually, effects don't, but change properties of components etc.

Parameters:
context The drawing context that specifies the surface and clipping rectangle for the drawing operation.
Note:
This method is called by the Desktop. Do not call it directly.

virtual bool execute (  DrawingContext &  context,
long  time
)  [virtual, inherited]
 

Performs operations for one frame, advancing the effect by the frame time.

Afterwards, the effect issues whether it is complete now.

Parameters:
context The drawing context that specifies the surface and clipping rectangle for the drawing operation.
time This frame's time in milli seconds. You should advance the effect by this amount.
Returns:
Whether to continue the effect. false will destroy it.
Note:
This method is called by the Desktop. Do not call it directly.

Reimplemented from Effect.

virtual bool executeTimed (  DrawingContext &  context,
long  time
)  [protected, virtual, inherited]
 

Performs operations for one frame, advancing the effect by the frame time.

If the remaining time of the effect's total time is less than the frame time, only the remaining time is passed to this method, and the end() method is called. If both methods return true, the execute() method is called again with the remainder of the frame time.

Parameters:
context The drawing context that specifies the surface and clipping rectangle for the drawing operation.
time This frame's time in milli seconds. You should advance the effect by this amount.
Returns:
Whether to continue the effect. false will destroy it.
Note:
This method is called by the Desktop. Do not call it directly.

Reimplemented from ComponentEffect.

long getElapsedTime (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the elapsed time in milli seconds for the effect.

If the effect is repetitive, this is the elapsed time for this loop.

Returns:

int getFocusAlphaDelta (   )  [inherited]
 

FocusingType getFocusingType (   ) 
 

void* getModel (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the application (or game) defined data.

Typically, there is an object that contains application data that corresponds to this graphical element. This object (or raw data) is stored here. Glaziery will not perform any operation on it, but you can use it to identify application objects for given event targets (such as components).

Returns:
The application (or game) defined data.

int getNonFocusAlphaDelta (   )  [inherited]
 

double getProgress (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the portion of the elapsed time to the total time, maybe translated by a time curve.

This value ranges from 0.0 to 1.0.

Returns:
The portion, starting at 0.0, ending at 1.0.

int getReferences (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the number of open references to this object.

Starts with zero. If no references remain, the object is automatically destroying itself.

Returns:
The number of references.

long getRemainingTime (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the remaining time in milli seconds for the effect.

If the effect is repetitive, this is the remaining time for this loop.

Returns:
The remaining time in milli seconds for the effect.

SkinData* getSkinData (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the skin specific settings and other skin data.

The skin data is managed by the skin. If you want to implement a skin independent application (or game), do not use this object outside the skin. However, if you know which skin is in use and you require to read or write special property, you may cast this object to the respective type. This object may be NULL, if the skin does not need to store any data.

Returns:
The skin specific settings and other skin data.
Note:
If the object is not null when the component is destroyed, then the skin data is automatically destroyed.

TimeCurve* getTimeCurve (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the time curve in use.

Translates the progress ranging from 0.0 to 1.0 to another value starting from 0.0, ending in 1.0, allowing acceleration and any other type of time curve. May be NULL, indicating to use a linear time curve.

Returns:
The time curve in use or NULL.

long getTotalTime (   )  [inherited]
 

Returns the total time of the effect in milli seconds.

If the effect is repetitive, this is the time of one loop.

Returns:
The total time of the effect in milli seconds.

void onComponentDestroying (   )  [protected, inherited]
 

virtual bool onEnd (  DrawingContext &  context  )  [protected, virtual]
 

Performs operations when the total time of the effect has elapsed.

The method can decide whether to restart the effect (loop).

Parameters:
context The drawing context that specifies the surface and clipping rectangle for the drawing operation.
Returns:
Whether to restart the effect. In this case, the onStart() and execute() methods are called again, and the time of the execute() method is the remainder of the time (i.e. the frame time minus the time passed to the execute() method of the previous loop.
Note:
This method is called by the Desktop. Do not call it directly. To cancel the effect, use cancel().

Reimplemented from CachableComponentEffect.

virtual bool onStart (  DrawingContext &  context  )  [protected, virtual]
 

Performs operations when the effect starts or restarts.

Parameters:
context The drawing context that specifies the surface and clipping rectangle for the drawing operation.
Returns:
Whether to continue the effect. false will destroy it.
Note:
This method is called by the Desktop. Do not call it directly.

Reimplemented from CachableComponentEffect.

void release (   )  [inherited]
 

Decreases a reference count by one.

If no references remain, the object is automatically destroying itself.

void setModel (  void *  model,
void(*  modelDestructor)(void *model) = NULL
)  [inherited]
 

Sets the application (or game) defined data.

Typically, there is an object that contains application data that corresponds to this graphical element. This object (or raw data) is stored here. Glaziery will not perform any operation on it, but you can use it to identify application objects for given event targets (such as components).

Parameters:
model The application (or game) defined data.
modelDestructor An optional static method that is called, whenever the glaziery object is destroyed or when a new model is set. Specify this function only, if the model must be destroyed by this glaziery object, i.e. the object "owns" the model. If the model is a glaziery object itself, you may use the GlazieryObject::destructor() function.
See also:
destructor()

void setNonFocusAlphaEnd (  unsigned char  nonFocusAlphaEnd  )  [inherited]
 

void setNonFocusAlphaStart (  unsigned char  nonFocusAlphaStart  )  [inherited]

bool  relative = false
)  [inherited]
 

void setPositionStart (  Vector  positionStart,
bool  relative = false
)  [inherited]
 

void setProgress (  double  getProgress  )  [inherited]
 

Sets the progress of this effect.

This value ranges from 0.0 to 1.0.

Note:
Use this method to adjust the progress of a running effect, for example if the effect situation changed. You should not use this method for repetitions or sequences.
Parameters:
progress The new value, starting at 0.0, ending at 1.0.
See also:
onEnd()

EffectSequence

void setRestoring (  bool  restoring  )

virtual void setSkinData (  SkinData *  skinData  )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Sets the skin specific settings and other skin data.

The skin data is managed by the skin. If you want to implement a skin independent application (or game), do not use this object outside the skin. However, if you know which skin is in use and you require to read or write special property, you may cast this object to the respective type. This object may be NULL, if the skin does not need to store any data.

Parameters:
skinData The skin specific settings and other skin data.
Note:
If the object is not null when the component is destroyed, then the skin data is automatically destroyed.

Any previously set skin data is automatically destroyed.

Reimplemented in Component.

void setTimeCurve (  TimeCurve *  timeCurve  )  [inherited]
 

Sets the time curve to use.

Translates the progress ranging from 0.0 to 1.0 to another value starting from 0.0, ending in 1.0, allowing acceleration and any other type of time curve.

Parameters:
timeCurve The time curve to be used. May be NULL, indicating to use a linear time curve. The method owns the time curve after setting it and will delete its memory when the effect is destroyed or when another time curve is set.
See also:
setTimeCurveToAcceleration()

void setTimeCurveToAcceleration (   )  [inherited]
 

Convenience method: Sets a new AccelerationTimeCurve into this effect.

See also:
setTimeCurve()

AccelerationTimeCurve

void setTotalTime (  long  totalTime  )  [inherited]
 

If the effect is repetitive, this method sets the total time of the next loop(s) in milli seconds.

Parameters:
totalTime The next loop(s) total time in milli seconds.

virtual String toString (   )  [virtual, inherited]
 

Returns a string reprensentation of this object.

The string representation.

Reimplemented in ClientArea, CachableComponent, Component, Desktop, Dialog, Button, CheckBox, Field, GroupField, ImageField, KeyStrokeField, Label, ListField::RowsField, ListField, ProgressBar, RadioBox, Selector, Slider, Spacer, TabbingField, TextField, TreeField, MenuBar, Popup, Scene, Widget, and Window.

void waitFor (   )  [inherited]
 

Performs the desktop's run loop until this effect has ended.

Use this method if you want to perform operations that need the completedness of this effect. This method calls Desktop::runOnce(), so it is possible that your code gets called in turn. Please be aware of this situation, maybe by added guard flags while calling this method.
